newsitem.title: VIETNAM: Vietnam daily says Communist Party under threat.
newsitem.headline: Vietnam daily says Communist Party under threat.

text.p: Vietnam's official army newspaper warned on Monday that the ruling Communist Party is under threat from forces seeking to sow disaffection among groups including intellectuals, young people and the military.

A signed commentary in the official Quan Doi Nhan Dan (People's Army) paper said imperialist forces were taking advantage of Vietnam's open-door policy to penetrate deeper into society to cause social and political instability.

The daily catalogued a list of targets ranging from party cadres and managers to intellectuals, young people, disaffected people, and dissident groups with overseas connections. It said the military was a prime target.

"...they (hostile forces) focus on measures to incite and cause disunity, create suspicion, carry out plots to use young cadres against old cadres, use 'communist son' against 'communist father'..." it said.
The blunt commentary added that enemies of Vietnam were seeking to pit "economic communists" against "military or police communists", and create a rift between the Party leadership and the military.
The Quan Doi Nhan Dan newspaper is seen as representing the views of the military in Vietnam.
It has carried a number of articles this year warning of the dangers of backdoor subversion, or 'peaceful evolution', but Monday's was the strongest in months.
Vietnam's ruling Communist Party is the sole legal political force in Vietnam and is normally sensitive to suggestions of internal disunity or disaffection.

It survived the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union and has maintained a policy since the late 1980s of seeking overseas investment and building links with foreign governments, regardless of ideology.
However, a five-year plan unveiled earlier this year outlined a need for tighter internal controls and greater policing of Vietnam's open-door policy.
